# Evil Queen (Disney)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

Evil Queen  
---

The **Evil Queen** , also known as the **Wicked Queen** or just the **Queen**
, and sometimes instead identified by her given name as **Queen Grimhilde** ,
is the primary [antagonist](/wiki/Antagonist "Antagonist") in
[Disney](/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company "The Walt Disney Company")'s 1937
animated film _[Snow White and the Seven
Dwarfs](/wiki/Snow_White_and_the_Seven_Dwarfs_\(1937_film\) "Snow White and
the Seven Dwarfs \(1937 film\)")_ and a villain character in the extended
[Disney's _Snow White_ franchise](/wiki/Snow_White_\(franchise\) "Snow White
\(franchise\)"). She is based on [the Evil Queen](/wiki/Queen_\(Snow_White\)
"Queen \(Snow White\)") character from the European [fairy
tale](/wiki/Fairy_tale "Fairy tale") "[Snow White](/wiki/Snow_White "Snow
White")".

In the film, similar to the [Brothers Grimm](/wiki/Brothers_Grimm "Brothers
Grimm") story, the Evil Queen is cold, cruel, and extremely vain, and
obsessively desires to remain the "fairest in the land". She becomes madly
envious over the beauty of her stepdaughter, Princess [Snow
White](/wiki/Snow_White_\(Disney_character\) "Snow White \(Disney
character\)"), as well as the attentions of the Prince from another land; such
[love triangle](/wiki/Love_triangle "Love triangle") element is one of
Disney's changes to the story. This leads her to plot the death of Snow White
and ultimately on the path to her own demise, which in the film is indirectly
caused by the [Seven Dwarfs](/wiki/Seven_Dwarfs "Seven Dwarfs"). The film's
version of the Queen character uses her dark magic powers to actually
transform herself into an old woman instead of just taking a disguise like in
the Grimms' story; this appearance of hers is commonly referred to as the
**Wicked Witch** or alternatively as the **Old Hag** or just the **Witch**.
The Queen dies in the film, but lives on in a variety of non-canonical Disney
works.

The film's version of the Queen was created by [Walt Disney](/wiki/Walt_Disney
"Walt Disney") and [Joe Grant](/wiki/Joe_Grant "Joe Grant"), and originally
animated by [Art Babbit](/wiki/Art_Babbit "Art Babbit") and voiced by [Lucille
La Verne](/wiki/Lucille_La_Verne "Lucille La Verne"). Inspiration for her
design came from the characters of Queen Hash-a-Motep from
_[She](/wiki/She_\(1935_film\) "She \(1935 film\)")_ and Princess
[Kriemhild](/wiki/Kriemhild "Kriemhild") from _[Die
Nibelungen](/wiki/Die_Nibelungen "Die Nibelungen")_. The Queen has since been
voiced by [Eleanor Audley](/wiki/Eleanor_Audley "Eleanor Audley"), [June
Foray](/wiki/June_Foray "June Foray"), [Janet Waldo](/wiki/Janet_Waldo "Janet
Waldo"), Eda Reiss Merin, [Louise Chamis](/wiki/Louise_Chamis "Louise Chamis")
and [Susanne Blakeslee](/wiki/Susanne_Blakeslee "Susanne Blakeslee"), and was
portrayed live by [Anne Francine](/wiki/Anne_Francine "Anne Francine")
(musical), [Jane Curtin](/wiki/Jane_Curtin "Jane Curtin") (50th anniversary TV
special), and [Olivia Wilde](/wiki/Olivia_Wilde "Olivia Wilde") (_Disney Dream
Portraits_), [Kathy Najimy](/wiki/Kathy_Najimy "Kathy Najimy")
(_[Descendants](/wiki/Descendants_\(2015_film\) "Descendants \(2015
film\)")_), and in an alternative version, by [Lana
Parrilla](/wiki/Lana_Parrilla "Lana Parrilla") (_[Once Upon a
Time](/wiki/Once_Upon_a_Time_\(TV_series\) "Once Upon a Time \(TV
series\)")_).

This version of the classic fairy tale character has been very well received
by film critics and the public, and is considered one of Disney's most iconic
and menacing villains. Besides in the film, the Evil Queen has made numerous
appearances in Disney attractions and productions, including not only these
directly related to the tale of Snow White, such as
_[Fantasmic!](/wiki/Fantasmic! "Fantasmic!")_ , _[The Kingdom
Keepers](/wiki/The_Kingdom_Keepers "The Kingdom Keepers")_ and _[Kingdom
Hearts Birth by Sleep](/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts_Birth_by_Sleep "Kingdom Hearts
Birth by Sleep")_ , sometimes appearing in them alongside
[Maleficent](/wiki/Maleficent "Maleficent") from _[Sleeping
Beauty](/wiki/Sleeping_Beauty_\(1959_film\) "Sleeping Beauty \(1959 film\)")_.
The film's version of the Queen has also become a popular
[archetype](/wiki/Archetype "Archetype") that influenced a number of artists
and non-Disney works.

## In _Snow White and the Seven
Dwarfs_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Evil_Queen_\(Disney\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: In Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs")]

Main article: [Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937
film)](/wiki/Snow_White_and_the_Seven_Dwarfs_\(1937_film\) "Snow White and the
Seven Dwarfs \(1937 film\)")

###
Storyline[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Evil_Queen_\(Disney\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Storyline")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/d1/Evil_Queen_Grimhilde.png/170px-
Evil_Queen_Grimhilde.png)](/wiki/File:Evil_Queen_Grimhilde.png)

[](/wiki/File:Evil_Queen_Grimhilde.png "Enlarge")

The Queen in her secret lair in an illustration by the [Brothers
Hildebrandt](/wiki/Brothers_Hildebrandt "Brothers Hildebrandt")

In "another land, far away,"[4] "many, many years ago," about the time of
[fairy tales](/wiki/Fairy_tale "Fairy tale") of castles, knights, fair
maidens, romance, magic and witches,"[5] a mysterious and icily beautiful
woman with magical powers (a 1938 promotional brochure suggests she is able to
work her [witchcraft](/wiki/Witchcraft "Witchcraft") having sold "herself body
and soul to the bad spirits" of the [Harz](/wiki/Harz "Harz") mountains[6])
has gained her royal position by seducing and marrying the widowed
[King](/wiki/King_\(Snow_White\) "King \(Snow White\)"), giving her rule over
his kingdom before he died. "From that time on the cruel Queen ruled all
alone, her every word was law, and all trembled in mortal fear of her
anger."[7] The vain Queen owned a magical mirror with which she could look
upon whatever she wished. The [Magic Mirror](/wiki/Magic_Mirror_\(Snow_White\)
"Magic Mirror \(Snow White\)") shows a haunted, smokey face of her [familiar
demon](/wiki/Familiar_spirit "Familiar spirit")[6] which replies to the
Queen's requests. She regularly asks the mirror who is the fairest in the
realm ("Magic mirror on the wall, who is the fairest one of all?" which is
often misquoted as "Mirror mirror on the wall, who is the fairest of them
all"[8][9]), and the mirror would always reply that she is.

One day, however, the mirror tells her that there is a new fairest woman in
the land, her 14-year-old[10] stepdaughter, Princess [Snow
White](/wiki/Snow_White_\(Disney_character\) "Snow White \(Disney
character\)"). She became obsessively jealous of the princess' emerging
beauty, therefore turning her into a [scullery maid](/wiki/Scullery_maid
"Scullery maid") in her own home. After observing the handsome Prince from
another kingdom singing a love song to Snow White, the proud Queen, in a
jealous rage, commands her faithful [Huntsman](/wiki/Huntsman_\(Snow_White\)
"Huntsman \(Snow White\)"), Humbert, to take the princess deep into the forest
and kill her. He is ordered to bring back her heart in a box to prove that he
had done so. But Humbert cannot bear to kill the young princess upon realizing
that she is impervious to harm, so he tells Snow White of the Queen's plot and
tells her to run away and never to come back. To escape the penalty, he comes
back with a pig's heart and gives it to the Queen. When she questions her
mirror, it again replies that Snow White is the fairest in the land, and that
she is living at the cottage of the [Seven Dwarfs](/wiki/Seven_Dwarfs "Seven
Dwarfs"), revealing that the box contains the heart of a pig. The Dwarfs are
fearful of the Queen's [black magic](/wiki/Black_magic "Black magic") but
decide to take in Snow White anyway.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/cf/Snow_White_Witch.jpg/170px-
Snow_White_Witch.jpg)](/wiki/File:Snow_White_Witch.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Snow_White_Witch.jpg "Enlarge")

The Witch (right) offering a poisoned apple to [Snow
White](/wiki/Snow_White_\(Disney_character\) "Snow White \(Disney
character\)") in [Gustaf Tenggren](/wiki/Gustaf_Tenggren "Gustaf Tenggren")'s
inspirational art for the film

Furious that Humbert tricked her, the Queen decides that first Snow White
shall die by her own hand and at any cost. She goes down the dungeon to her
secret room where she practices her dark magic, complete with a pet raven that
"knows all her secrets,"[11] and in desperation uses her spellbook and
cauldron to mix a potion that transforms her into a [hag](/wiki/Hag "Hag").
Her beauty is shrouded in ugliness and age, though presumably reversible.[12]
She then conjures a poison apple, which will cause "the Sleeping Death",[13]
and proceeds to leave the castle via a moat boat. She is sure that no one
would know or perform the counter-curse to her spell, and believes the Dwarfs
would bury her rival alive, thinking her dead. The Queen comes to the cottage,
followed by two vicious vultures, and finds Snow White baking a pie for Grumpy
the dwarf. Somehow Snow White's animal friends realize that the old hag is the
Queen. After an unsuccessful attempt to warn Snow White by attacking the
Queen, they go to warn the Dwarfs of the Queen's arrival. The Queen tricks the
princess into letting her inside the cottage and eating the bewitched apple,
telling her that it is a magic wishing apple. Snow White takes a bite and
falls to the floor, apparently dead.

The Queen rejoices in her victory, but is soon discovered by the angry Seven
Dwarfs, who grab pickaxes and chase her deep into the forest as a great storm
begins. She climbs up into the mountains, where she gets trapped upon a
precipice that overlooks a seemingly bottomless canyon. She tries to push down
a large boulder to crush the approaching Dwarfs. Before she can do so, a
lightning bolt strikes between her and the boulder, destroying the precipice
and sending the Queen (along with the boulder) down the cliff to her death,
screaming while she falls to the jagged rocks below (this scream was reused in
_[Sleeping Beauty](/wiki/Sleeping_Beauty_\(1959_film\) "Sleeping Beauty \(1959
film\)")_ when [Maleficent](/wiki/Maleficent "Maleficent") is stabbed in the
heart by the Sword of Truth). As the Dwarfs look wide-eyed over the cliff's
edge, they cannot see her, but the vultures descend into the chasm. The
Queen's dark reign is over, and her castle is then taken over and the revived
Snow White and the Prince who broke the spell. (A 1936 pre-release _[Good
Housekeeping](/wiki/Good_Housekeeping "Good Housekeeping")_ novelization by
Dorothy Ann Blank, a member of the film's story team, affirms that the Queen
in fact dies: "Far below, in a chasm as dark as her own wicked soul, lay the
body of the hateful Queen. No magic would ever bring her to life again."[7])

### Conception, design and
portrayal[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Evil_Queen_\(Disney\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Conception, design and portrayal")]

Early concepts for the film called for a "fat, batty, cartoon type, self-
satisfied" Queen. However, [Walt Disney](/wiki/Walt_Disney "Walt Disney")
became concerned that such an approach would make the character seem less
plausible. Sensing that more time was needed for the development of the Queen,
he advised that attention be paid exclusively to "scenes in which only Snow
White, the Dwarfs, and their bird and animal friends appear."[14] Disney
further developed the main plot himself ([Ollie Johnston](/wiki/Ollie_Johnston
"Ollie Johnston") said the film's story was based on the idea that the Queen's
character was going to murder "another drawing" and Disney decided to make it
appear believable[15]), finding a dilemma in the characterization of the
Queen, whom he envisioned as a mixture of [Lady Macbeth](/wiki/Lady_Macbeth
"Lady Macbeth") and the [Big Bad Wolf](/wiki/Big_Bad_Wolf "Big Bad
Wolf"),[16][17] and decided to set on "a high collar stately beautiful
type"[18] whose "beauty is sinister, mature, plenty of curves – she becomes
ugly and menacing when scheming."[10] According to the 1993 Disney Classics
series of trading cards, "she is really two characters, the beautiful evil
Queen and the grotesquely evil witch."

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Naumburg-
Uta.JPG/170px-Naumburg-Uta.JPG)](/wiki/File:Naumburg-Uta.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Naumburg-Uta.JPG "Enlarge")

Statue of [Uta von Ballenstedt](/wiki/Uta_von_Ballenstedt "Uta von
Ballenstedt") at the [Naumburg Cathedral](/wiki/Naumburg_Cathedral "Naumburg
Cathedral") in [Naumburg](/wiki/Naumburg_\(Saale\) "Naumburg \(Saale\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Rh_louise_crawford26.png/170px-
Rh_louise_crawford26.png)](/wiki/File:Rh_louise_crawford26.png)

[](/wiki/File:Rh_louise_crawford26.png "Enlarge")

[Joan Crawford](/wiki/Joan_Crawford "Joan Crawford") c. 1930

The Queen's appearance was inspired by the "ageless ice goddess"[19] character
of Queen Ayesha ("She who must be obeyed") from the 1935 film
_[She](/wiki/She_\(1935_film\) "She \(1935 film\)")_ , played by [Helen
Gahagan](/wiki/Helen_Gahagan "Helen Gahagan").[20][21] The Queen was
originally to be named Grimhilde[10] (but who is never actually named in the
film[22]), was also modeled in part on Princess [Kriemhild](/wiki/Kriemhild
"Kriemhild") in the 1924 film _[Die Nibelungen](/wiki/Die_Nibelungen "Die
Nibelungen")_.[23] It is also possible that the Queen's looks may have been
inspired by the faces of [Joan Crawford](/wiki/Joan_Crawford "Joan
Crawford")[24] and [Gale Sondergaard](/wiki/Gale_Sondergaard "Gale
Sondergaard");[25] her costume and figure may have been inspired by a column
statue at the [Naumburg Cathedral](/wiki/Naumburg_Cathedral "Naumburg
Cathedral") depicting [Uta von Ballenstedt](/wiki/Uta_von_Ballenstedt "Uta von
Ballenstedt"), the wife of [Eckard II, Margrave of
Meissen](/wiki/Eckard_II,_Margrave_of_Meissen "Eckard II, Margrave of
Meissen") who was widely regarded as the most beautiful woman of [Medieval
Germany](/wiki/Germany_in_the_Middle_Ages "Germany in the Middle
Ages").[26][27] Also noted was her resemblance to two 1930s American movie
stars from Europe, [Greta Garbo](/wiki/Greta_Garbo "Greta Garbo") and [Marlene
Dietrich](/wiki/Marlene_Dietrich "Marlene Dietrich").[28] The Queen and Snow
White were refined by [Grim Natwick](/wiki/Grim_Natwick "Grim Natwick") and
[Norm Ferguson](/wiki/Norm_Ferguson_\(animator\) "Norm Ferguson
\(animator\)"), who would often override Walt Disney's instructions.[29] As in
the case of other characters for the film, the Queen's appearance had to be
approved by Albert Hurter before being finalised.[14] One pre-final version of
the queen had her wear a looser hood and a different crown and the edge of her
cape was fur trimmed, as it can be seen in [Gustaf
Tenggren](/wiki/Gustaf_Tenggren "Gustaf Tenggren")'s pictures.[30][31]

None of [Art Babbit](/wiki/Art_Babbit "Art Babbit")'s lead animation work on
the character was [rotoscoped](/wiki/Rotoscoping "Rotoscoping")[32][33] and
the animators were noted to prefer to draw the Queen over Snow White "because
she was more real and complex as a woman, more erotic, and driven to desperate
acts by her magic mirror."[34] The character, however, turned out to be
especially problematic for the animators, as she had to be "regally beautiful,
with confined but graceful movements," and "the experiments on her lovely
cruel mouth and eyes alone represent drawings enough to fill a paper
house."[35] The sequence of her transformation in particular was the film's
toughest to visualise using trick effects,[36] especially since Disney
insisted on showing how the Queen felt as she changed.[35]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Alc%C3%A1zar_de_Segovia-7.jpg/170px-
Alc%C3%A1zar_de_Segovia-7.jpg)](/wiki/File:Alc%C3%A1zar_de_Segovia-7.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Alc%C3%A1zar_de_Segovia-7.jpg "Enlarge")

[Alcázar of Segovia](/wiki/Alc%C3%A1zar_of_Segovia "Alcázar of Segovia") in
2011

According to a description in her card in the Disney Villains set, "the
Witch's ugliness symbolises the evil disguised by the Queen's beauty." Her
castle might have been inspired by Spain's [Alcázar of
Segovia](/wiki/Alc%C3%A1zar_of_Segovia "Alcázar of Segovia")[37][38][39] and
the throne she is uses has a [peacock
motif](/wiki/Peafowl#Cultural_significance "Peafowl") to symbolise her extreme
vanity.[40] The Queen is clad mostly in black and other "negative" dark
colors, providing a contrast to Snow White's bright colorful wardrobe,[41] and
has "shiny black hair" under her hood.[7] Her royal costume was painted with
specially developed paints made to look like satin for her collar and like
velvet for her robe.[35] The Queen's music tracks were created with low celio
notes, basses, and bassoons; the scribblings in her book of spells were
written in Italian.[42]

Notably, the Queen was the first character to ever speak in an animated
feature film.[43] She was voiced by [Lucille La Verne](/wiki/Lucille_La_Verne
"Lucille La Verne"), who achieved her voice change for the role of the Witch
by removing her false teeth.[44] [Joe Grant](/wiki/Joe_Grant "Joe Grant"), who
contributed the design for her Witch form,[45] noticed La Verne's changing
attitude and posture when voicing the Queen and Witch, and sketched these
poses and her [body language](/wiki/Body_language "Body language") down for
animation reference.[46] He also said he based the Witch's concept art on a
woman who lived across the street from him.[47] The character's foreign
dubbing voice actresses included [Jiřina
Petrovická](/wiki/Ji%C5%99ina_Petrovick%C3%A1 "Jiřina Petrovická") in
Czechoslovakia, [Clara Pontoppidan](/wiki/Clara_Pontoppidan "Clara
Pontoppidan"), [Kirsten Rolffes](/wiki/Kirsten_Rolffes "Kirsten Rolffes"),
[Lise Ringheim](/wiki/Lise_Ringheim "Lise Ringheim") in Denmark, [Rauni
Luoma](/wiki/Rauni_Luoma "Rauni Luoma") and [Seela Sella](/wiki/Seela_Sella
"Seela Sella") in Finland, [Claude Gensac](/wiki/Claude_Gensac "Claude
Gensac") in France, [Dagny Servaes](/wiki/Dagny_Servaes "Dagny Servaes") in
Germany, [Ilus Vay](/wiki/Ilus_Vay "Ilus Vay") in Hungary, [Tina
Lattanzi](/wiki/Tina_Lattanzi "Tina Lattanzi") and [Dina
Romano](/wiki/Dina_Romano "Dina Romano") in Italy, [Tanie
Kitabayashi](/wiki/Tanie_Kitabayashi "Tanie Kitabayashi") in Japan, [Blanca de
Castejón](/wiki/Blanca_de_Castej%C3%B3n "Blanca de Castejón") and [Cristina
Montt](/wiki/Cristina_Montt "Cristina Montt") in Mexico, [Zinaida
Sharko](/wiki/Zinaida_Sharko "Zinaida Sharko") in Russia, and [Helena
Brodin](/wiki/Helena_Brodin "Helena Brodin"), [Hjördis
Petterson](/wiki/Hj%C3%B6rdis_Petterson "Hjördis Petterson") and [Lil
Terselius](/wiki/Lil_Terselius "Lil Terselius") in Sweden.

The Queen was also the first character to meet death in a Disney film.[48] As
part of elimination of the original story's more gruesome aspects, and to make
Snow White seem more a "nice girl",[6] the Wicked Queen is no longer
cannibalistic and her destruction was made "just as certain but more merciful"
than in the original story, where she is forced to dance to her death in red-
hot iron shoes on her feet as an invited guest at Snow White's
wedding.[31][49] Snow White's role in the Queen's demise is removed, and the
Queen "dies more neatly and quickly,"[6] as justice is served without
resorting to killing or torture. She also invites her own downfall while
pushing the boulder, and her fate is only suggested rather than shown.[50] One
of the Witch's animators was [Ward Kimball](/wiki/Ward_Kimball "Ward
Kimball"), whom Walt Disney also let to draw the two vultures watching her
fall "to make it a little easier" for him, as Kimball has been reassigned
after his own sequence was cut from the film,[51] since Disney thought these
additional dwarfs gag scenes would distract from "the real drama" of the
tension between Snow White and her wicked stepmother that was supposed to
drive the film.[52]

### Abandoned
concepts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Evil_Queen_\(Disney\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Abandoned concepts")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Evil_Queen%27s_Dungeon_2.jpg/170px-
Evil_Queen%27s_Dungeon_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Evil_Queen%27s_Dungeon_2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Evil_Queen%27s_Dungeon_2.jpg "Enlarge")

A gargoyle ornament in the Queen's dungeon in [Snow White's Scary
Adventures](/wiki/Snow_White%27s_Scary_Adventures "Snow White's Scary
Adventures")

The original outline of the story featured the Queen's attempt to kill Snow
White with a poisoned comb, an element taken from the Grimms' version of the
tale (the Dwarfs would arrive in time to remove it). The envious Queen would
also decide to take possession of Snow White's attractive young suitor, the
18-year-old[10] Prince (described in a press kit as "every woman's dream
man"[36]) for herself, offering him an opportunity to share the throne with
her through a marriage.[53][54] With the Prince refusing to marry her, the
Queen would have him captured by her guards and taken to her dungeon to be
suspended in chains in a [torture chamber](/wiki/Torture_chamber "Torture
chamber").[55] She would later visit him there and used her sorcery to taunt
him by bringing the dungeon's skeletons (also chained to the walls) to life
and making them dance, identifying one skeleton as "Prince Oswald",[10] only
for the Prince to defy her again. She then has him given to the torturers,
described as "the [Nubians](/wiki/Nubia "Nubia")",[56] and "exits with a dirty
laugh."[57]

According to production story-meeting notes from October 1934, "Queen wants to
marry Prince, but he refuses to acknowledge 'that she is the fairest in the
land,' since he has seen Snow White."[58] It is written in story notes that
the Queen has magical power only over her own domain, which is the castle.[56]
Another note states about their meeting in the dungeon: "This is a sequence of
gruesome comedy ― of dancing skeletons ― fantastic shadows ― witchcraft and
deviltry."[59] The name Prince Oswald was an inside joke reference to [Oswald
the Lucky Rabbit](/wiki/Oswald_the_Lucky_Rabbit "Oswald the Lucky
Rabbit").[54] The Queen was originally intended to have seven [black
panthers](/wiki/Black_panther "Black panther") guarding the entrance to her
secret room with the Mirror;[7] a concept art of the Queen walking a pet
panther can be seen in [The Walt Disney Family
Museum](/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Family_Museum "The Walt Disney Family Museum")
and at [Disney California Adventure](/wiki/Disney_California_Adventure "Disney
California Adventure").

The books _Snow White: Magic Mirror Book_ and _The Complete Story of Walt
Disney 's Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs_ reveal that the Huntsman was afraid
to disobey a command to kill Snow White because the Queen's might feed him to
her panthers or shrink him magically "to the size of a walnut".[53][60] In one
1937 novelization, the Queen vows the Huntsman would pay dearly for allowing
her stepdaughter to escape, but first she would deal with Snow White
herself.[61] In another version, the Huntsman would too be dragged to the
dungeon when the Queen finds out that he has betrayed her,[53] and the Queen
might smash her own Mirror in anger.[54][62] Later, after transforming
herself, she decides to punish the Prince for having scorned her. She informs
the Prince of her plan to have the Dwarfs bury Snow White alive and then
leaves him to his death, still chained and trapped in a subterranean chamber
filling with water[45] to slowly drown. She then makes her way to the Dwarfs'
cottage with the poisoned apple, while birds and forest animals were to help
the Prince escape the Queen's minions and find his horse as would race to try
and save Snow White.[63][64]

This plotline described above was not used in the final film, although it was
carried out to the drawing and [cel](/wiki/Cel "Cel") stage,[65] and several
inspirational sketch pictures of the dungeon scenes were drawn by Ferdinand
Hovarth. It is said that Disney "knew that the Queen would have to look scary
without being too scary."[16] Some skeletons are briefly featured in the
finished film in the other parts of the dungeon,[66] except in Australia's
censored original theatrical release version.[67] Similar motifs and scenes
were later used in _Sleeping Beauty_[31][64] and
_[Aladdin](/wiki/Aladdin_\(1992_Disney_film\) "Aladdin \(1992 Disney
film\)")_. Elements of this sub-plot have also made their way into some other
Disney's _Snow White_ fiction and visitor attractions.
