suspects (and sometimes the culprit)[79] in the interactive gallery Midship
Detective Agency's story "The Case of The Plundered Paintings".

### Film and
television[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Evil_Queen_\(Disney\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Film and television")]

The Queen is featured in some Disney television specials like _[Our Unsung
Villains](/wiki/Our_Unsung_Villains "Our Unsung Villains")_ (1956) and
_[Disney's Greatest Villains](/wiki/Disney%27s_Greatest_Villains "Disney's
Greatest Villains")_ (1977). Segments of the Queen's appearance are also shown
in _[Disney's Halloween Treat](/wiki/Disney%27s_Halloween_Treat "Disney's
Halloween Treat")_ (1982) and in _[A Disney
Halloween](/wiki/A_Disney_Halloween "A Disney Halloween")_ (1983). She makes
small cameo appearances in the animated series _[Disney's House of
Mouse](/wiki/Disney%27s_House_of_Mouse "Disney's House of Mouse")_, voiced by
[Susanne Blakeslee](/wiki/Susanne_Blakeslee "Susanne Blakeslee") (where she is
seen sitting with [Lady Tremaine](/wiki/Lady_Tremaine "Lady Tremaine") in her
queen form, and with [Madam Mim](/wiki/Madam_Mim "Madam Mim") and [Witch
Hazel](/wiki/Witch_Hazel_\(Disney\) "Witch Hazel \(Disney\)") in her witch
form) and in the films _[Who Framed Roger
Rabbit](/wiki/Who_Framed_Roger_Rabbit "Who Framed Roger Rabbit")_ (1988) and
_[Runaway Brain](/wiki/Runaway_Brain "Runaway Brain")_ (1995), shown there in
her witch form.

In the live-action television special _Disney 's Golden Anniversary of Snow
White_ (1987), the Queen is played by [Jane Curtin](/wiki/Jane_Curtin "Jane
Curtin") in a parodic scenario.[80] She casts a spell on Grumpy in an attempt
to get him to persuade the other Dwarfs to retire and destroy the original
film after the 50 years. After the failure of this, her Mirror convinces her
to finally quit "this whole curse business" and focus on her current career as
a television [horror host](/wiki/Horror_host "Horror host").

The Queen (voiced by Susanne Blakeslee) is the main villain in the 2005
direct-to-video animated film _[Once Upon a
Halloween](/wiki/Once_Upon_a_Halloween "Once Upon a Halloween")_ , but appears
only in the Witch version despite misleading cover art (furthermore, only her
shadow is shown). In it, the Queen plots to conquer Halloween and asks her
cauldron to show several villains to which one of them helps her in her plan.
The cauldron also explains its origins as it is one of the cauldrons formerly
owned by the three witches from _[The Black
Cauldron](/wiki/The_Black_Cauldron_\(film\) "The Black Cauldron \(film\)")_.
Eventually, the cauldron turns against the Wicked Queen and makes her vanish
into nothingness.

In [Mike Disa](/wiki/Mike_Disa "Mike Disa")'s and [Evan
Spiliotopoulos](/wiki/Evan_Spiliotopoulos "Evan Spiliotopoulos")' abandoned
pitch for the [DisneyToons](/wiki/DisneyToons "DisneyToons")' _Snow White_
prequel film _The Seven Dwarfs_ , a beautiful girl named **Narcissa** appears
to aid the dwarfs against an evil wizard, who would be eventually revealed as
her father whom she would betray and trap him inside a mirror. Narcissa steals
the ancient magic secrets of the Olden Dwarfs, marries and then murders Snow
White's father, and "begins her reign as the Evil Queen, with the damned soul
of her own father forever encased in the Magic Mirror as her slave. Thus, the
dwarfs must live in hiding to protect their families from the Queen's
vengeance." Three computer-animated sequels to _The Seven Dwarfs_ "were to
follow the title characters return home to families and friends after the Evil
Queen's death in _Snow White_."[81][82]

In a 2015 [Disney Channel Original Movie](/wiki/Disney_Channel_Original_Movies
"Disney Channel Original Movies") titled
_[Descendants](/wiki/Descendants_\(2015_film\) "Descendants \(2015 film\)")_ ,
the aged Evil Queen (played by [Kathy Najimy](/wiki/Kathy_Najimy "Kathy
Najimy")[83]) is among a host of other villains who have been imprisoned on a
forbidden Isle of the Lost,[84] and her daughter Evie (played by Sofia
Carson)[85] is among their offspring who are allowed to return into the
kingdom to attend school alongside the offspring of iconic Disney heroes
(Evie's father is unidentified.). The Evil Queen is portrayed as Maleficent's
closest confident and best friend. Its title image features the iconic red
apple of the Evil Queen,[86][87] which was also prominently featured in a
teaser trailer.[88] Carson was cast to return as Evie in _[Descendants
2](/wiki/Descendants_2 "Descendants 2")_.

In Justin Merz's and [Evan Daugherty](/wiki/Evan_Daugherty "Evan Daugherty")'s
script for the live-action spin-off _Rose Red_ , currently in development,
Snow White's sister Rose Red is going to "join Grumpy and the fellow Dwarves
on a journey to find the Evil Queen and break her curse."[89]

###
Books[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Evil_Queen_\(Disney\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Books")]

In the 1949 audiobook release, the Queen (voiced by [Eleanor
Audley](/wiki/Eleanor_Audley "Eleanor Audley")) wears a yellow dress and a red
cape. She tells the Huntsman to take Snow White to the forest and leave her
there to die. In the end of the book, after being chased by the dwarfs, the
Queen dies when she slips while climbing the mountain and falls into the sea.

The novel _Fairest of All: A Tale of the Wicked Queen_ by Serena Valentino,
published by [Disney Press](/wiki/Disney_Press "Disney Press") in 2009,[90]
tells a story much more sympathetic to the Queen than most other Disney media.
The book shows how the Queen became the villain from the film, much in the
style of _[The Killing Joke](/wiki/Batman:_The_Killing_Joke "Batman: The
Killing Joke")_ , with the Magic Mirror, here possessed by the spirit of her
abusive father, having been a corrupting influence. According to the book, her
mother was a witch and the King died in a war against another kingdom prior to
the events of the film. After her husband's death, the Queen slowly descends
into madness. By the end of novel, Snow White gets the mirror and the Queen
becomes the spirit inside the mirror after her death in the film.

The Queen is one of the Overtakers, villains of _[The Kingdom
Keepers](/wiki/The_Kingdom_Keepers "The Kingdom Keepers")_ novel series. She
was introduced in 2011 in the fourth book of the saga, _Power Play_ ,
alongside Cruella De Vil. Like Maleficent, she is very powerful and is able to
cast almost any spell with a flick of her finger; she can also transform
herself and other characters. In _Power Play_ , when Maleficent and
[Chernabog](/wiki/Chernabog "Chernabog") are captured by the Keepers, the
Queen becomes the new leader of the Overtakers.

One chapter in [Todd Strasser](/wiki/Todd_Strasser "Todd Strasser")'s 1993
_Disney 's the Villains Collection/Stories from the Films_ is dedicated to
_Snow White_ and the Queen. She is also a subject of one of the illustrated
books in the Disney Princess series _My Side of the Story_ , titled _Snow
White/The Queen_ (2004), which portrays her as a misunderstood positive
character.[91]

[Melissa de la Cruz](/wiki/Melissa_de_la_Cruz "Melissa de la Cruz") wrote the
_Descendants_ prequel novel _Isle of the Lost_.[92] In that book, it is
revealed that the Evil Queen once tried to overthrow Maleficent as the ruler
of the Isle.

### Theatrical
shows[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Evil_Queen_\(Disney\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Theatrical shows")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Fantasmic%21_Evil_Queen.jpg/220px-
Fantasmic%21_Evil_Queen.jpg)](/wiki/File:Fantasmic!_Evil_Queen.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Fantasmic!_Evil_Queen.jpg "Enlarge")

The Queen with her magic cauldron during _[Fantasmic!](/wiki/Fantasmic!
"Fantasmic!")_ show in 2013

As in the film, the Queen character is featured in 1979 _[Snow White and the
Seven Dwarfs](/wiki/Snow_White_and_the_Seven_Dwarfs_\(musical\) "Snow White
and the Seven Dwarfs \(musical\)")_ musical version, played by [Anne
Francine](/wiki/Anne_Francine "Anne Francine").[93] In the [Disney on
Ice](/wiki/Disney_on_Ice "Disney on Ice") reenactment of the movie in
1986-1987,[94] and then in 1994–1997 and again in 2000–2001, she was voiced by
[Louise Chamis](/wiki/Louise_Chamis "Louise Chamis") and played by various
skaters beginning with Melanie Scott in 1986-1987,[95][96] and including Elena
Koteneva, who was substituted by Davina Lee-Gooding in 1995.[97] Francine also
played her in the 1980 stage play and television program _Snow White Live_[98]
and Chamis voiced her in [Disneyland](/wiki/Disneyland "Disneyland")'s _Snow
White – An Enchanting Musical_ in 2004 and 2006. The Evil Queen was also
featured in [Disney Live](/wiki/Disney_Live "Disney Live")'s _Three Classic
Fairy Tales_ in the section based on the film.[99][100]

In the night-time fireworks and visual hydrotechnic show
_[Fantasmic!](/wiki/Fantasmic! "Fantasmic!")_ , first played in 1992, the
Queen, voiced by Louise Chamis, is the main villain and the leader of all the
[Disney Villains](/wiki/Disney_Villains "Disney Villains"). She is introduced
in the second act, when her Magic Mirror (voiced by [Tony Jay](/wiki/Tony_Jay
"Tony Jay")) tells her that there are now three princesses (Snow White,
[Ariel](/wiki/Ariel_\(Disney_character\) "Ariel \(Disney character\)") and
[Belle](/wiki/Belle_\(Disney\) "Belle \(Disney\)")) fairer than her. Enraged,
the Queen transforms herself into a hag[101] and uses the Mirror and her
cauldron to summon various "all the forces of evil"[102] in the form of a
collection of Disney villains to come to her aid. They include Maleficent, who
transforms into a dragon. (In the [Tokyo DisneySea](/wiki/Tokyo_DisneySea
"Tokyo DisneySea") version, she also traps [Mickey](/wiki/Mickey_Mouse "Mickey
Mouse") inside her mirror.) At the climax of the show, Mickey is able to
defeat the dragon and vanquish all the villains with a magic sword. The Witch
is the last to die, transforming back into the Queen before she is destroyed.

In the _[Disney Dream](/wiki/Disney_Dream "Disney Dream")_ cruise ship show
_Villains Tonight!_ , first played in 2010, [Hades](/wiki/Hades_\(Disney\)
"Hades \(Disney\)") calls forth Disney's most powerful villains for help to
regain his evil. The Queen, changing from the Witch form, denies his
invitation since Hades also invited Maleficent, her rival for Hades'
affections and for the status of "the most evil in the land". The Queen claims
not to be Hades' girlfriend, but they just had "an interesting weekend" on
[Castaway Cay](/wiki/Castaway_Cay "Castaway Cay"). In the end, the Queen and
Maleficent put their differences aside as all villains should stick together
and advise Hades to find evil within himself, and not from others.

###
Games[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Evil_Queen_\(Disney\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Games")]

The Witch is an antagonist in the unreleased _Snow White_ game for the [Atari
2600](/wiki/Atari_2600 "Atari 2600").[103] In 2001's _Walt Disney 's Snow
White and the Seven Dwarfs_ for the [Game Boy Color](/wiki/Game_Boy_Color
"Game Boy Color"), the players need to solve a puzzle minigame for the Queen
to consult her mirror, and later guide a deer to warn the Dwarfs and then lead
the Dwarfs in pursuit of the Witch before he can go to her castle.

The Queen is one of the four Disney Villains that appear in 1999 video game
_[Disney's Villains' Revenge](/wiki/Disney%27s_Villains%27_Revenge "Disney's
Villains' Revenge")_, voiced by Louise Chamis. [Jiminy
Cricket](/wiki/Jiminy_Cricket "Jiminy Cricket") and the player venture into
the worlds of the stories to restore the happy endings. In the altered (and
game's final) story, where there is no Prince, the Queen (appearing in both of
her forms) has built a lair resembling her poisoned apple inside the scary
wood, and has put Snow White to eternal sleep in her dungeon and intends to do
the same to the Seven Dwarfs. The player needs to correctly mix ingredients
for several potions including the True Love Potion to magically summon the
Prince and save the day. It is followed by the fight with the Queen where she
tries to get away and the player has to reflect her magic ball spells, until
she retreats to her lair. There, while asking her mirror, she suddenly
transforms into a hag and the mirror breaks.

In 2010's video game _[Kingdom Hearts: Birth by
Sleep](/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts:_Birth_by_Sleep "Kingdom Hearts: Birth by Sleep")_
, the Queen (voiced by Kyoko Satomi in Japanese and Susanne Blakeslee in
English) appears in the Dwarf Woodlands world. She recruits the protagonist
[Terra](/wiki/Terra_\(Kingdom_Hearts\) "Terra \(Kingdom Hearts\)") to kill
Snow White and bring back her heart in return for allowing him to use the
Magic Mirror to locate Master Xehanort. Terra, like the huntsman, ultimately
does not go through with this, and the Queen, learning of his betrayal, forces
the Mirror to consume him, but Terra manages to fight the Mirror off and the
Queen reluctantly gives him the information he looks for. She later appears
briefly in Ventus's scenario, where she crosses paths with him on her way to
poison Snow White. She drops the poisoned apple, which Ventus returns to her.
She notices Ventus's Keyblade and muses that Terra threatened her with a
similar weapon. She is then only briefly mentioned in
[Aqua](/wiki/Aqua_\(Kingdom_Hearts\) "Aqua \(Kingdom Hearts\)")'s storyline,
when the Magic Mirror tells Aqua that the Queen is dead and he is no longer
under her control.

In 2013's free-to-play mobile game _Snow White: Queen 's Return_ (also known
as _Seven Dwarfs: The Queen 's Return_),[104] an uncanonical continuation of
the film, the Queen has survived the fall at the climax of the film because
there was a lake at the bottom of the abbyss. She then reverted to her
youthful form and, seeking revenge, cast an evil curse on Snow White as well
as the dwarfs and their entire forest.[105] The game's updates were supposed
to allow the players to "meet (and defeat)" the Queen,[106] adding quests
involving a search for her hideout[107] to "help the Dwarfs rid the enchanted
forest of the evil queen,"[108] but the story was ultimately left unresolved
as the game was discontinued in May 2014.

A 2014 weekly challenge in _Disney Infinity: Toy Box_ included "Mirror Mirror"
obstacle course that pit Snow White against the Evil Queen in a race for the
poisonous apple.[109] Downloadable Queen-themed avatar costumes were made
available for the users of the [PlayStation 3](/wiki/PlayStation_3
"PlayStation 3") and [Xbox 360](/wiki/Xbox_360 "Xbox 360") video game
consoles.[110][111] A webcam browser game _Become Your Inner Villain_ hosted
on Disneyland Resort’s [Facebook](/wiki/Facebook "Facebook") page enables the
player turn into one of four villains including the Evil Queen.[112] Her
dungeon and laboratory (complete with the Mirror) are featured in the online
game _Aaah-Choo_.[113]

In the 1990 video game _[Castle of Illusion Starring Mickey
Mouse](/wiki/Castle_of_Illusion_Starring_Mickey_Mouse "Castle of Illusion
Starring Mickey Mouse")_ , an old witch named Mizrabel takes
the[_[clarification needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please
clarify")_] of the Evil Queen after draining the youth from [Minnie
Mouse](/wiki/Minnie_Mouse "Minnie Mouse"). In 2012's _[Epic Mickey: Power of
Illusion](/wiki/Epic_Mickey:_Power_of_Illusion "Epic Mickey: Power of
Illusion")_ , the previously defeated Mizrabel returns to transform into
various Disney villains, including the Queen,[114] before setting on
Maleficent. In 2013's [HD remake of _Castle of
Illusion_](/wiki/Castle_of_Illusion_Starring_Mickey_Mouse_\(2013_video_game\)
"Castle of Illusion Starring Mickey Mouse \(2013 video game\)"), Mizrabel
looks like a cross between the Queen and Maleficent in her youthful form and
professes her ambition to be "the fairest of them all".

The Evil Queen is also featured in a number of traditional games, albeit
usually as a mere obstacle for the players.[115][116][117] She is, however,
playable in some of them, such as _Snow White and the Severn Dwarfs Game_ in
the Disneykins franchise[118] and _Disney Villains Collector 's Edition
Monopoly_.[119]

Jim Razzi's 1985 children's gamebook _Snow White in the Enchanted Forest
(Choose Your Own Adventure: Walt Disney #1)_ features the Prince-like
character's confrontations with evil Queen as she is searching for Snow White,
who is hiding with the Dwarfs, to "put an end to her, once and for all!"[120]
In it, she has much greater powers than in the film, including being able to
instantly change between her hag and queen forms at will,[121] magically
disappear in a cloud of smoke,[122] change herself into an animal and back,
and turn others into animals with magic beams from her hands.[123]

###
Comics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Evil_Queen_\(Disney\)&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Comics")]

The 1937–1938 film tie-in serial comic strip "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs"
written by [Merrill De Maris](/wiki/Merrill_De_Maris "Merrill De Maris"), one
of the writers of the film,[124] is centred primarily around the relationship
between Snow White and the Queen. It further explores the source of the
Queen's descent into a murderous envy, as she learns that the Prince came to
her castle seeking the most beautiful woman in all the world and is shocked
when he says he meant Snow White. Like in the abandoned film concept, the
Queen (here actually named Grimhilde) has the Prince arrested. In her Witch
form, she later tells the captive Prince that she is going to get rid of Snow
White and make him hers, while the Prince is defiant and calls her a
"miserable hag".[10] This scene is followed by his escape from prison, in much
less dramatic circumstances than the film's drowning concept.[125] The film
was also adapted into an other comics including in 1969,[126] 1983,[127] and
1991.[128]

There is a number of comics set in the film's world. One early comic _Pamuk
Prenses ile Sevimli Prens_ (1942) tells of the further adventures of Snow
White and Prince Charming, the Witch returns to put a spell on the
latter.[129][130] In one American 1944 sequel comic, the dead Queen's castle
is taken over by her brother, the Wicked Prince.[131] Later comics usually
feature the Queen in her Witch incarnation,[132] often with her still trying
to eliminate either Snow White ("The Seven Dwarfs and Thumper",[133] "No Ritmo
Da Bruxa",[134] "A Maçã Superenfeitiçada",[135] "Kerstverhaal"[136]) or the
dwarfs ("The Enchanted Mountain",[137] "Halloween"[138]). Such stories include
[Jack Bradbury](/wiki/Jack_Bradbury "Jack Bradbury")'s stand-alone 1958 comics
_Mystery of the Missing Magic_[139] and _A New Adventure of Snow White and the
Seven Dwarfs_.[140] In the comic "The Seven Dwarfs and the Witch-Queen",[141]
the Witch shrinks all the dwarfs except of Dopey who manages to save his
brothers.[142] In "A Pirate's Tale" (aka "The Pirate"[143]), the greedy old
Witch transforms herself into a rat as she plans to steal a treasure and turn
the dwarfs into cheese and eat them, but Dopey destroys her with a cat.[144]

Usually under the alias the Witch, she often comes back to interact (usually
to antagonize, but sometimes also to occasionally cooperating with
protagonistic characters) with other Disney characters.[145] She has appeared
in the comics of April, May and June,[146] the [Beagle Boys](/wiki/Beagle_Boys
"Beagle Boys"),[147] [Br'er Rabbit](/wiki/Br%27er_Rabbit "Br'er Rabbit"),[148]
[Chip 'n Dale](/wiki/Chip_%27n_Dale "Chip 'n Dale"),[149] [Donald
Duck](/wiki/Donald_Duck "Donald Duck") & Mickey Mouse,[150]
[Goofy](/wiki/Goofy "Goofy"),[151] [Huey, Dewey, and
Louie](/wiki/Huey,_Dewey,_and_Louie "Huey, Dewey, and Louie"),[152] Jiminy
Cricket,[153] [José Carioca](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Carioca "José Carioca"),[154]
Mickey & Minnie Mouse,[155] Li'l Bad Wolf,[156] [Tinker
Bell](/wiki/Tinker_Bell "Tinker Bell"),[157] the Three Little Pigs,[158] and
the fellow witches such as Madam Mim from _[The Sword in the
Stone](/wiki/The_Sword_in_the_Stone_\(film\) "The Sword in the Stone
\(film\)")_ ,[159] Witch Hazel from _[Trick or
Treat](/wiki/Trick_or_Treat_\(1952_film\) "Trick or Treat \(1952 film\)")_ ,
and [Magica De Spell](/wiki/Magica_De_Spell "Magica De Spell") (especially in
Brazilian comics).[160] She also starred in the 1970s-1980's comic book series
_The Big Bad Wolf & The Wicked Witch_, including "Mirror Mirror",[161] "Witch
Switch",[162] "The Apple Caper",[163] "The High-Hopping Wolf",[164] "Double
Trouble",[165] and "Getting the Boot".[166]

Several comics include the Witch kidnapping another Disney character, either
to be her slave or to exchange them for something, until they are rescued.
Example of this include her abducting, besides Snow White ("Diamond Dust
Dilemma",[167] "The Weather Witch"[168]), such characters as Chip 'n' Dale
("Witch Convention",[169]), Tinker Bell ("Pixie Dust Dilemma"[170] "The Big
Bust-out"[171]), and _[Dumbo](/wiki/Dumbo "Dumbo")_ characters ("Dumbo".[172]
"The Chips Are Flying",[173] "A Witch in Time"[174]). The Witch also captures
Dumbo in "Dumbo l'échappe belle",[175] but is defeated by Mickey and [Br'er
Bear](/wiki/Br%27er_Fox_and_Br%27er_Bear "Br'er Fox and Br'er Bear") and
imprisoned by the Dwarfs.[176] In "The Gingerbread House", the Witch captures
the [Wicked Witch of the West](/wiki/Wicked_Witch_of_the_West "Wicked Witch of
the West")'s children Witch Child and Warlock whom Magica De Spell was tasked
to look after.[177] Another recurring motif is the Witch's attempts to turn
characters into gold, for example Pinocchio ("The Magic Brew"[178]) or all the
forest animals ( "Get Rich Witch"[179]). She may also simply try to steal the
treasures, from either the Dwarfs ("Snow White and The Seven Dwarfs",[180]
"Verjongingsdrank"[181]) or other characters ("Black Magic Menace",[182]
"Pursuit of Plunder"[166]). In the prequel story _Battle of Wits and Witches_
, the Queen turns into the hag to steal a diamond from the Dwarfs but is foile
by Mickey and Goofy.[183] She also repeatedly attempts to ruin Christmas, like
in "The Golden Christmas Tree", where she lures Huey, Dewey and Louie to her
lair use their tear drops in a magic potion to destroy all the Christmas trees
in the world,[184] and in "Delivery Problems" where she plots to put Santa
Claus' reindeer to sleep.[185]

In the _[Walt Disney's Comics and
Stories](/wiki/Walt_Disney%27s_Comics_and_Stories "Walt Disney's Comics and
Stories")_ parody of _[The Wonderful Wizard of
Oz](/wiki/The_Wonderful_Wizard_of_Oz "The Wonderful Wizard of Oz")_ , "The
Wizard of Bahs" by [Vic Lockman](/wiki/Vic_Lockman "Vic Lockman") and
Strobl,[186] the Witch is unexpectedly turned into an old tree trunk by [Daisy
Duck](/wiki/Daisy_Duck "Daisy Duck") while her castle turns to sand.[187] In
"The Captured Castle", the Witch captures Cinderella's castle,[188] and in
"It's Snow Joke" she turns Dale's snow dragon alive.[189] In "The Magic Spell"
Chip 'n' Dale steal her flying powder.[190] The Witch's Magic Wand is obtained
by Goofy in "Magic-Mender"[191] and stolen by the Big Bad Wolf in "The Magic
Wand".[192] In "The Haunted House Caper", the Witch turns Donald Duck's into a
haunted one,[193] a story continued in "13 Blackcat Road".[194] In _O
Sindicato Das Bruxas_ , José Carioca fights against her syndicate of
witches.[195] In "The Washed-up Witch",[196] where she ends up deprived of her
powers and accepting [Scrooge McDuck](/wiki/Scrooge_McDuck "Scrooge McDuck")'s
offer to become his private secretary.[197][198] In "The Sitter Solution",
Mickey hires the Witch as a babysitter for Morty and Ferdie.[199]

Many stories, notably usually featuring the Queen in her youthful form, have
been first published in Italian Disney digest comic series,[200] in particular
in _[Topolino](/wiki/Topolino "Topolino")_. They include "The Seven Dwarfs and
the Evil Witch" (_I Sette Nani e la Strega Malvagia_), "Snow White and the
Broken Mirror" (_Biancaneve e lo specchio infranto_),[201] "The Seven Dwarfs
and the Spell of the Queen" (_I Sette Nani e l 'incantesimo della
regina_),[202] "Snow White and the Castle of Four Winds" (_Biancaneve al
castello dei quattro venti_),[203] "The Seven Dwarfs and the Heroic Antieve"
(_I Sette Nani e l 'eroica antivigilia_),[204] "The Seven Dwarfs and the Brew
of Seven Herbs" (_I Sette Nani e l 'infuso delle sette erbe_ aka "The Seven
Herbs Spell!"),[205] "Snow White and the Silver Rose" (_Biancaneve e la rosa d
'argento_),[206] and "The Seven Dwarfs and the Joker Wizard" (_I Sette Nani e
il mago burlone_),[207] among others. For instance, "Snow White and the
Shattered Mirror" (_Biancaneve e lo specchio infranto_),[208] has the old
Witch, terminally ill, discover she has only one day to live, but she refuses
to accept her destiny and finds a way to conquer death. In "Goofy the Magician
and the Seven Dwarfs" (_Pippo mago e i Sette Nani_),[209] the Queen's four
goon henchmen attack the dwarfs and steal their treasure but then decide to
keep it for themselves and Grimhilde seeks help from the wizard Abracadabro to
stop their run; eventually, it is the Prince who defeats the robbers. "Donald
Fracasse: (_Paperin Fracassa_) is a parody of the adventure film _[Captain
Fracasse](/wiki/Captain_Fracasse_\(1961_film\) "Captain Fracasse \(1961
film\)")_ in which Snow White is blinded by the Queen and Donald Duck needs to
heal her. In "The Seven Dwarfs and Christmas in Danger" (_I Sette Nani e il
Natale in pericolo_)[210] the Queen goes to steal a comet stardust as the last
ingredient for her spell to destroy Snow White. In "The Seven Dwarfs and the
Covenant of the Queen" (_I Sette Nani e il patto della regina_),[211] she
conjures the demon Shadow Lord Oren and makes a pact with him to take the soul
of Snow White. She once again attempts to eliminate Snow White with the help
of seven evil dwarfs, but in doing so she burns ends up burning all of her
vital energy and Oren takes her with him.[212] "The Seven Dwarfs and the
Christmas Fairy" (_I Sette Nani e la fatina di Natale_) presents a scenario in
which the Queen successfully casts a forever-sleep enchantement on Snow White,
but while trying to zap Dopey she accidentally falls victim of her own
witchcraft and the Christmas fairy, freed from her prison, saves Snow
White.[213][214] In Italian comics, the Queen is usually wearing a red robe.
She is also often shown using a [crystal ball](/wiki/Crystal_ball "Crystal
ball") to spy on the good characters.[205][206][215]

Many of the _Topolino_ Snow White comics were the works of [Romano
Scarpa](/wiki/Romano_Scarpa "Romano Scarpa"). His 1986 comic "The Seven Dwarfs
and King Arbor's Crystal" (_I Sette Nani e il cristallo di Re Arbor_) provides
explanation how the Queen would have survived her apparent death in the film
(as some branches and bushes eased the fall and she was rescued by her loyal
guards) and why she could not change back to her normal self (as her castle
was burned down by the Huntsman and her book of magic is gone). In this story,
Grimhilde (Grimilde) enlists the aid of her great admirer and past suitor, the
evil King Arbor of Vegetalia, in a plot to use a magic crystal device to swap
her old body with Snow White's.[216][217] The intrigue is foiled by the
dwarves who destroy the crystal, and the resigned Arbor allows the Witch to
live with her, saying he will try to remember she _was_ "the most beautiful
among queens". The uneasy relationship between Grimhilde and Abor continued in
the comic "The Seven Dwarfs and the Fountainhead" (_I Sette nani e la fonte
meravigliosa_),[218][219] in which she desperately attempts to regain her
youth, but instead only turns into a childlike version of her Witch form for a
short time.

Other comics by Romano Scarpa have the Queen in her youthful form.[220] In the
three-part "Snow White and the Green Flame" (_Biancaneve e verde
fiamma_),[215][221][222] the Queen flies on a broom to the great gathering of
witches, who declare that her inability to deal with just a little girl and
few dwarfs has disgraced them all and she should be punished for this
according to the laws of Hell. The Queen begs the High Witch for mercy and is
given a magic wand with the power of transformation, but if she would not
succeed this time she will be turned into a magic broom for a more "honorable"
witch to fly. The Queen uses the wand to gain trust of Snow White and turn her
a figurine, than takes the princess' form to ambush the dwarfs and do the same
with them, and waits for the Prince's arrival to kill him. Only Dopey escapes
and eventually manages to outwit the Queen, using her want to restore his
friends and transform her into a figurine, which later turns into a broom when
her sentence is carried over. In "The Seven Dwarfs and the Throne of Diamonds"
(_I Sette Nani e il trono di diamanti_),[223] Jiminy Cricket is deeply
enamored by the Queen's beauty and attempts to convince her to become good,
but the Queen refuses to be redeemed and orders her soldiers to steal the
throne the Dwarfs make for Snow White in a plot to turn her rival into an old
woman. Eventually, the Queen is defeated by another witch Tardona and Snow
White is saved. "Snow White and the Chained Fairy" (_I Sette Nani e la fata
incatenata_),[224] sees the dwarfs struggle to free the fairy Fawn who was
captured by the Queen in an underground cavern for saving Snow White when
Grimhilde flew to strike down the princess with a thunderbolt. She takes on
many forms trying to thwart them in various ways, and one-by-one the dwarfs
sacrifice their lives, until only Dopey remains but he manages to get hold of
magical water that brings back all of them to life. The freed fairy's magic
makes the cavern collapse down on the helpless Queen to make sure she will
never hurt anyone again. In "The Seven Dwarfs and the Birtch Ring" (_I Sette
Nani e l 'anello di betulla_ by Romano Scarpa),[225] the Queen learns about
the eight Dwarf named Ginger (Zenzero), who has left the his companions to go
in search of fortune traveling the world, and transforms into a pixie named
Fagottina to send him home and sow discord among his brothers.[226] The Queen
also transforms into a pixie, named Fogliolina, in "Snow White and Easter in
the Woods" (_Biancaneve e la Pasqua nel bosco_),[227] where, after her attempt
to kill Snow White with magic is foiled by woodland creatures, she is so
enraged that she calls upon the infernal powers to "take her" and her castle
burns into flames and crumbles around her. In "The Seven Dwarfs and the Wolf's
Cliff" (_I Sette Nani e la balza del lupo_),[228] she sends three of her
bandit minions (Bragia, Sghembo and Schidione) to kidnap Snow White. "Snow
White and the Bewitched Dress" (_Biancaneve e l 'abito stregato_)[229] has the
Queen magically disguise herself as an old gypsy to give Snow White a cursed
dress and capture her, then start her work on the spell to rid of the dwarfs
and all the forest creatures. But Dopey infiltrates her castle, frees Snow
White, and locks up the Queen in her laboratory set ablaze, after which the
whole castle is consumed by fire and explodes after the dwarf and the princess
escape.

The Queen also appears as one of the villains in the 2005 Disney manga series
_[Kilala Princess](/wiki/Kilala_Princess "Kilala Princess")_ by Rika Tanaka
and Nao Kodaka, where the protagonists Rei and Kilala Reno find themselves in
the world of Snow White, and meet and befriend the princess. They go the
Queen's castle to ask the Magic Mirror how to find Kilala's friend Erika, but
discover the Queen is still alive (and even commanding the two vultures, as
well as wolves) as she appears and demands Kilala's magical tiara. The
children try to flee but are attacked by wolves and locked up in the dungeon,
where the Queen transforms into the Witch and prepares to turn Kilala into an
ugly creature. Snow White appears and agrees to sacrifice herself to save
them, but Kilala stops her at last moment before she can eat a poison apple;
Rei then attacks the Queen, who falls into her cauldron, turns into a vulture,
and flies away in a defeat.

###
Merchandise[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Evil_Queen_\(Disney\)&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Merchandise")]

The character was also featured in a wide variety of Disney merchandise, such
as in the Designer Villains "stylized and fashion-forward" series of limited
edition dolls and make-up products,[230] or the Wickedly Beautiful entry in
the Beautifully Disney collection of cosmetic products.[231] Various other
such merchandise include many dolls,[232][233] figurines/statuettes,[234][235]
costumes,[236] clothing items,[237][238] watches/clocks/mirrors,[239][240] key
chains/blanks,[241] mugs,[242][243] other tableware,[244][245]
bags/purses/suitcases,[246][247] containers,[248][249]
prints/posters/cards/stickers,[250][251] pins/buttons/magnets,[252][253]
holiday ornaments,[254] plush toys,[255] puzzles,[256] other beauty
products,[257][258] and so forth.[259] In one issue of _[Disney
Adventures](/wiki/Disney_Adventures "Disney Adventures")_ in 1997, the Evil
Queen appeared on the cover attempting to woo [Will Smith](/wiki/Will_Smith
"Will Smith").[260][261]

One hand-made figure costing $2,000 was the most expensive out of 200,000
items being sold at the Disney World shopping village in 1985.[262] During an
auction in 1988, an animation cel from the iconic scene of the Queen holding
her heart box sold for a record-setting price of $30,000.[263] In 1997,
another cel from the same scene sold for $21,275 and a cel of the Witch
offering an apple to Snow White realized $13,800.[264] Another cel showing the
Queen reading her spellbook sold for $8,050 in an earlier in auction in
1995.[265] In 2015, a Hag cell was sold on an aution for $48,000.[266]

## In _Once Upon a
Time_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Evil_Queen_\(Disney\)&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: In Once Upon a Time")]

Main article: [Regina Mills](/wiki/Regina_Mills "Regina Mills")

An almost entirely alternate take on the character of the Evil Queen is Regina
Mills, the main antagonist in the first season of the 2011
[ABC](/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company "American Broadcasting Company")
live-action TV series _[Once Upon a Time](/wiki/Once_Upon_a_Time_\(TV_series\)
"Once Upon a Time \(TV series\)")_ where she is played by [Lana
Parrilla](/wiki/Lana_Parrilla "Lana Parrilla"). Regina is the mayor of the
idyllic town of Storybrooke, Maine, but is secretly the Evil Queen of legend,
having cursed many beloved fairytale characters to live in a land without
magic, where they will never get their happy endings. The show is not directly
based on the Disney animated films, but is inspired by them and makes many
references to them. One of its episodes is titled "[The Evil
Queen](/wiki/The_Evil_Queen_\(Once_Upon_a_Time\) "The Evil Queen \(Once Upon a
Time\)")".

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Evil_Queen_\(Disney\)&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Critical reception and
popularity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Evil_Queen_\(Disney\)&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Critical reception and popularity")]

The Disney version of the character was very well received by film critics,
even as some were disturbed (columnist [Dorothy
Kilgallen](/wiki/Dorothy_Kilgallen "Dorothy Kilgallen") for instance urged
Disney to not make future villains as scary as the Witch[52]). [Stephen
Hunter](/wiki/Stephen_Hunter "Stephen Hunter") included her being "cool" among
the "wonderful truths about _Snow White_."[267] [Janet
Maslin](/wiki/Janet_Maslin "Janet Maslin") wrote the film's Snow White "exists
only to be victimized by her wicked stepmother - a far more interesting
character. The image of the wicked Queen (initially conceived as a raven-
haired glamour girl, and the epitome of late-1930s sophistication) who drinks
an aging potion and then shrivels, sprouting warts and claws, turning before
our eyes from a sexy, voluptous creature into a freightening old crone, must
leave as powerful an impression on the audience as Snow White's chirpy
feminity."[268] Similarly, [Roger Ebert](/wiki/Roger_Ebert "Roger Ebert")
wrote _Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs_ was "not so much about Snow White as
it was about the Seven Dwarfs and the Evil Queen," opining this was the reason
it has remained "the ultimate animated masterpiece" by 2001 instead of having
been forgotten soon after its premiere in 1937.[269]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Morgan_McMichaels_%28Evil_Queen%29.jpg/170px-
Morgan_McMichaels_%28Evil_Queen%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Morgan_McMichaels_\(Evil_Queen\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Morgan_McMichaels_\(Evil_Queen\).jpg "Enlarge")

[Morgan McMichaels](/wiki/Morgan_McMichaels "Morgan McMichaels") dressed as
the Queen in 2015

Feminism academic [Camille Paglia](/wiki/Camille_Paglia "Camille Paglia") said
that she used to be transfixed by this "temperamental diva bitch", due to the
contrast with the ideal of womanhood that she had been presented to as a
child: "[Mary](/wiki/Mary,_mother_of_Jesus "Mary, mother of Jesus"), this
silent mother; and here was the witch queen who has this weird dialogue in the
mirror and it didn't have to be charitable and it didn't have to be nice. I
thought she was fabulous."[270] Likewise, [Lana Parrilla](/wiki/Lana_Parrilla
"Lana Parrilla"), who later herself played the Evil Queen in _Once Upon A
Time_ , said that whenever she watched Disney's _Snow White_ as a young girl
she rooted for and "loved the evil queen―every time the evil queen came on, I
was like 'OK!' She was just so fascinating to me."[271] Author [Deborah
Lipp](/wiki/Deborah_Lipp "Deborah Lipp") wrote: "As I've said before and will
doubtless say again, given a choice of being Snow White (helpless, sweet,
voiceless) and the Wicked Queen, with the cool castle and the magic and the
minions, give me my Magic Mirror _now!_ "[272] Film director [John
Waters](/wiki/John_Waters_\(director_born_1946\) "John Waters \(director born
1946\)") said he too rooted for the evil queen to win,[273] and [Chay
Yew](/wiki/Chay_Yew "Chay Yew") said that if he were a Disney character, he
would be the evil queen from _Snow White_.[274]

_Once Upon the Time_ co-creator [Adam Horowitz](/wiki/Adam_Horowitz "Adam
Horowitz") said that his earliest Disney memory was seeing a re-release of
Disney's _Snow White_ when he was "terrified by the Evil Queen while also
being unable to look away and that stuck with me through the years."[275]
Similarly, fashion designer and [Angelina Jolie](/wiki/Angelina_Jolie
"Angelina Jolie")'s _[Maleficent](/wiki/Maleficent_\(film\) "Maleficent
\(film\)")_ collaborator [Stella McCartney](/wiki/Stella_McCartney "Stella
McCartney") said: "My favorite Disney film was _Snow White_. I remember
growing up watching [it] and being completely freaked out by that scene where
the evil queen becomes the old witch and she makes the poison apple."[276]
Film maker and actor [Terry Gilliam](/wiki/Terry_Gilliam "Terry Gilliam")
listed the film's Queen among his eight favourite villains, commenting how
"truly strange" is that "vanity and beauty are what she's all about, yet the
identity she assumes when she becomes the old beggar woman is practically the
ugliest in all the kingdom."[277] Fairy tale lecturer [Jack
Zipes](/wiki/Jack_Zipes "Jack Zipes") alike noted that "it is somewhat strange
that the queen believes the mirror, for the picture of Snow White reveals that
she is a pretty pubescent red-cheeked ordinary girl while the queen is a
stunning beautiful mature woman who might easily win a beauty contest."[34]

Jim Lentz, Director of Animation Art at [Heritage
Auctions](/wiki/Heritage_Auctions "Heritage Auctions"), said in 2015: "The
Evil Queen is, to this day, one of the great villains of cinema, and she was
at her terrifying best when she became the Old Hag and set off to destroy Snow
White."[278] According to film maker and actor [Brad Bird](/wiki/Brad_Bird
"Brad Bird"), back in 1937 "they had to re-upholster the seats in a very large
movie palace in New York because little kids were peeing on the seats when the
witch came on in _Snow White_."[279] The Queen ranked as tenth in the
[American Film Institute](/wiki/American_Film_Institute "American Film
Institute")'s 2003 list of the [50 Best Movie Villains of All
Time](/wiki/AFI%27s_100_Years...100_Heroes_%26_Villains "AFI's 100 Years...100
Heroes & Villains"), being the highest-ranked animated villain.[280] When
[Walt Disney Parks and Resorts](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Parks_and_Resorts "Walt
Disney Parks and Resorts") held their 2011 Disney Villains popularity poll for
Wicked Gooey Apple Awards (named after the Queen's poison apple), the Evil
Queen came first and won in three out of five categories: "Sinister Stylings"
(for the most fashionable villain), "Curses! Foiled Again!" (for the villain
who received the best comeuppance), and the ultimate "Unfairest of Them All"
(for the most evil villain).[281] Jeff Kurtti's 2005 book _Disney Villains:
The Top Secret Files_ ranks her as "the greatest villain of them all".

In 2013, the Queen was among the 20 terrifying kids' movie characters by
_[Digital Spy](/wiki/Digital_Spy "Digital Spy")_ , commenting that "[Julia
Roberts](/wiki/Julia_Roberts "Julia Roberts") and [Charlize
Theron](/wiki/Charlize_Theron "Charlize Theron") may have taken a stab at this
role in two competing 2012 blockbusters, but they didn't get anywhere near the
kind of creepiness of Disney's evil Queen,"[282] as well as among ten scariest
Disney villains of all time by [entertainment.ie](/wiki/Entertainment.ie
"Entertainment.ie").[283] In 2014, [E!](/wiki/E! "E!") ranked "the original
head bitch in charge" as the seventh top Disney Villain,[284] while
[WatchMojo.com](/wiki/WatchMojo.com "WatchMojo.com") ranked her as the ninth
top Disney animated villain[285] and the fifth greatest female movie villain
of all time.[286] [Nerdist](/wiki/The_Nerdist_Podcast "The Nerdist Podcast")
put the Disney Villainesses "starting in 1937 with the Evil Queen" at top spot
in a 2015 ranking of "most bad ass" female villains in pop culture,[287] while
_[Gay Times](/wiki/Gay_Times "Gay Times")_ ranked her third among the "top
five wicked women of Disney"[288] and [MTV](/wiki/MTV "MTV") listed her as one
of the nine Disney Villains who were "way better than the good guys."[289]
That same year, [Moviepilot](/wiki/Moviepilot "Moviepilot") included her among
the seven most terryfying and evil Disney Villains as "she may be the
prettiest woman in the list, but sadly, that beautiful facade covers an ugly
and wicked soul,"[290] while [Gulf News](/wiki/Gulf_News "Gulf News"), ranking
her as the second greatest Disney Villain, commented she "still stands today -
78 years after the release of the first movie," as the most evil personality
that Disney has ever created.[291] Moviepilot also proposed "Disney could give
Snow White the Maleficent treatment and make a version telling the story
through the Evil Queen’s perspective,"[292] suggesting she should be played by
[Megan Fox](/wiki/Megan_Fox "Megan Fox").[293] In 2016, [The
Frisky](/wiki/The_Frisky "The Frisky") described her and Maleficent as "two of
the best-realized female villains in movie history."[294]

### Cultural
impact[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Evil_Queen_\(Disney\)&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Cultural impact")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Solweig_Rediger-
Lizlow_-_Cannes.JPG/170px-Solweig_Rediger-Lizlow_-
_Cannes.JPG)](/wiki/File:Solweig_Rediger-Lizlow_-_Cannes.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Solweig_Rediger-Lizlow_-_Cannes.JPG "Enlarge")

French model and TV host Solweig Rediger-Lizlow dressed as the Queen at the
[2012 Cannes Film Festival](/wiki/2012_Cannes_Film_Festival "2012 Cannes Film
Festival")

According to [Maria Tatar](/wiki/Maria_Tatar "Maria Tatar"), an academic
specializing in children's literature, the film turned "the evil queen into a
figure of gripping narrative energy and makes Snow White [the character] so
dull that she requires a supporting cast of seven to enliven her scenes.
Ultimately it is the stepmother's disruptive, disturbing, and divisive
presence that invests the film with a degree of fascination that has
facilitated its widespread circulation and that has allowed it to take such
powerful hold in our own culture."[295] [Alan Charles
Kors](/wiki/Alan_Charles_Kors "Alan Charles Kors") and [Edward
Peter](/wiki/Edward_Peter "Edward Peter") credited the Queen's character's
influence in changing the popular visual image of witches in film and other
fiction as specifically female, more often young and attractive than old and
ugly, and dressed in a characteristically defining costume.[296] A part of
[Maila Nurmi](/wiki/Maila_Nurmi "Maila Nurmi")'s inspiration for her character
of Vampira came from Nurmi being fascinated by the Queen after watching
Disney's _Snow White_ at the age of 14.[297] When she was cast for the 1939's
_[The Wizard of Oz](/wiki/The_Wizard_of_Oz_\(1939_film\) "The Wizard of Oz
\(1939 film\)")_ as the [Wicked Witch of the
West](/wiki/Wicked_Witch_of_the_West "Wicked Witch of the West"), [Gale
Sondergaard](/wiki/Gale_Sondergaard "Gale Sondergaard") (who herself has
earlier served as one of inspirations for Disney) insisted on playing a
glamorous vision of the character, similar to the Disney's interpretation of
the Queen from _Snow White_ ; when Sondergaard's idea was rejected by
producers [Mervyn LeRoy](/wiki/Mervyn_LeRoy "Mervyn LeRoy") and [Arthur
Freed](/wiki/Arthur_Freed "Arthur Freed") in favor of making the Wicked Witch
ugly, she withdrew from the project and [Margaret
Hamilton](/wiki/Margaret_Hamilton_\(actress\) "Margaret Hamilton \(actress\)")
was cast instead.[25] Still, the similarities between the two films, including
the porteayals on their respective witch characters, were such that _The
Wizard of Oz_ was at one point advertised as "_Snow White_ with live
actors."[298]

The Queen inspired main antagonist characters in the otherwise unrelated
titles, such as the stepmother queen in the Russian animated film _[The Wild
Swans](/wiki/The_Wild_Swans_\(film\) "The Wild Swans \(film\)")_ (1962),[299]
the Witch Queen in the Spanish film _[Tom Thumb and Little Red Riding
Hood](/wiki/Tom_Thumb_and_Little_Red_Riding_Hood "Tom Thumb and Little Red
Riding Hood")_ (1962),[300] the goddess Venus in the anime version of
_[Unico](/wiki/Unico "Unico")_ ,[301] Queen Admira in the American film _[The
Hugga Bunch](/wiki/The_Hugga_Bunch "The Hugga Bunch")_ (1985),[302] and the
queen of the witches in the video game _[Curse of
Enchantia](/wiki/Curse_of_Enchantia "Curse of Enchantia")_ (1992).[303] [Lady
Macbeth](/wiki/Lady_Macbeth "Lady Macbeth") in [Orson
Welles](/wiki/Orson_Welles "Orson Welles")' 1948
_[Macbeth](/wiki/Macbeth_\(1948_film\) "Macbeth \(1948 film\)")_ resembles the
Queen in her costume, make-up, and even the manner of her death;[304] Lady
Macbeth was also visually based on the Queen in a 1982 comic book
adaptation.[305] The evil Queen Bavmorda from 1988's film
_[Willow](/wiki/Willow_\(film\) "Willow \(film\)")_ bears a resemblance
too,[306] so much that _[Cinefantastique](/wiki/Cinefantastique
"Cinefantastique")_ editor Frederick S. Clarke described her as "simply _Snow
White '_s Wicked Queen, right down to her hooded costume."[307] [Robin
Wood](/wiki/Robin_Wood_\(critic\) "Robin Wood \(critic\)") has drawn a
connection between the looks of the Witch and of [the Emperor](/wiki/Palpatine
"Palpatine") in the _[Star Wars](/wiki/Star_Wars "Star Wars")_ franchise
(which eventually also became a Disney property).[308] According to the
designer Steve Brown, the Queen's old Witch form served as an inspiration for
the main character Witch Queen in his 1985 video game
_[Cauldron](/wiki/Cauldron_\(video_game\) "Cauldron \(video game\)")_.[309]
[Brigitte Nielsen](/wiki/Brigitte_Nielsen "Brigitte Nielsen") said she has
also based her role as the Black Witch (who also kidnaps a prince character
out of jealously for a princess) in the 1992 Italian film _[Fantaghirò
2](/wiki/Fantaghir%C3%B2_2 "Fantaghirò 2")_ on Disney's "Grimilde" (an Italian
name for the Queen in the comics).[310]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Mickey%27s_Not_So_Scary_Halloween_Party_-
_Villians_Stage_Show_%283%29.jpg/220px-
Mickey%27s_Not_So_Scary_Halloween_Party_-
_Villians_Stage_Show_%283%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mickey%27s_Not_So_Scary_Halloween_Party_-
_Villians_Stage_Show_\(3\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mickey%27s_Not_So_Scary_Halloween_Party_-
_Villians_Stage_Show_\(3\).jpg "Enlarge")

The Wicked Queen with several other [Disney villains](/wiki/Disney_villains
"Disney villains"), including [Maleficent](/wiki/Maleficent "Maleficent") and
the [Queen of
Hearts](/wiki/Queen_of_Hearts_\(Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland\) "Queen of
Hearts \(Alice's Adventures in Wonderland\)")

An official Disney.com blog Oh My Disney stated the Evil Queen has been "the
original Disney villain, and we’re really not exaggerating."[311] According to
_[The Daily Telegraph](/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph "The Daily Telegraph")_ , La
Verne's role as the Queen "was credited as the model for such future villains
as [Ursula](/wiki/Ursula_\(Disney\) "Ursula \(Disney\)") in _[The Little
Mermaid](/wiki/The_Little_Mermaid "The Little Mermaid")_ (1989) and
[Scar](/wiki/Scar_\(The_Lion_King\) "Scar \(The Lion King\)") in _[The Lion
King](/wiki/The_Lion_King "The Lion King")_ (1994)."[46] Maleficent from
_Sleeping Beauty_ inherited a number of characteristics from the Queen,
including the cowl, high collar, billowing cloak, arched eyebrows, cruel lips,
and raven familiar. An abandoned concept from _Snow White_ was that the Queen
kidnap the Prince and lock him in her dungeon; similarly, in _Sleeping Beauty_
, Maleficent kidnaps Prince Philip.[312] Lady Bane, a vain evil sorceress from
_[Disney's Adventures of the Gummi
Bears](/wiki/Disney%27s_Adventures_of_the_Gummi_Bears "Disney's Adventures of
the Gummi Bears")_, too bears a similarity to the Evil Queen in her costume
and character. Four wicked witches of the East, West, North and South,
resembling the Witch from Disney's _Snow White_ , are also the villains Mickey
has to kill to save Disneyland in 1988's _Mickey Mouse: The Computer
Game_.[313] The first names for the magic-wielding antagonist couple [The
Glooms](/wiki/The_7D#The_Glooms "The 7D") in Disney XD's own series _[The
7D](/wiki/The_7D "The 7D")_ (2014) ― set in a timeframe before the Seven
Dwarfs first met Snow White ― might have been inspired by the Evil Queen
character's alternate name "Grimhilde", with the bumbling
[warlock](/wiki/Warlock "Warlock") husband named "Grim" and the determined
witch wife named "Hildy".

The Queen's character design from the film was also used in some other Snow
White adaptations, such as for the Queen in the Turkish film _Pamuk Prenses ve
Yedi Cüceler_ (1970).[314] Queen Naga in Italian erotic comic books
_[Biancaneve](/wiki/Biancaneve "Biancaneve")_ was at first loosely based on
the Disney version, as was its Snow White's character.[315][316] [Susan
Sarandon](/wiki/Susan_Sarandon "Susan Sarandon")'s character of Queen Narissa
in Disney's own _[Enchanted](/wiki/Enchanted_\(2007_film\) "Enchanted \(2007
film\)")_ (2007), had her characteristics, powers, and physical features were
inspired by the Queen from the film and by Maleficent from _Sleeping
Beauty_.[317] Early on into the project, _Enchanted_ was actually supposed to
be a direct-to-video animated sequel to Disney's _Snow White_ (with a working
title of "_Snow White 2_ ") in which Narissa (back then often misspelled as
"Noriss") was the evil Queen's sister who would kidnap six of the dwarfs to
lure Snow White, the Prince, and their 13-year-old daughter Rose aided by
Dopey, into a trap.[318] When [Filmation](/wiki/Filmation "Filmation")
announced their own animated sequel to the fairy tale, the studio was sued by
Disney until Filmation promised their characters would not resemble the ones
from the Disney film; the settlement stated there could not be a "wicked
witch" character in the film which instead was made to feature the Queen's
brother in a vendetta to avenge her death (the title was also changed, from
_Snow White in the Land of Doom_ to _[Happily Ever
After](/wiki/Happily_Ever_After_\(1993_film\) "Happily Ever After \(1993
film\)")_).[319][320]

The Queen's castle was used prominently in the advertising of the film (acting
as the backdrop of the film's poster). Later Disney fairy tales, including
_[Cinderella](/wiki/Cinderella_\(1950_film\) "Cinderella \(1950 film\)")_ ,
_Sleeping Beauty_ , _The Little Mermaid_ , _[Beauty and the
Beast](/wiki/Beauty_and_the_Beast_\(1991_film\) "Beauty and the Beast \(1991
film\)")_ and _Aladdin_ , feature similarly fantastical castles and palaces,
and often these buildings act as centrepieces or backdrops for the movies'
posters. A fairy tale castle stands at the centre of each Disney theme park,
and the image of the castle is used in the logo for [Buena Vista
International](/wiki/Buena_Vista_International "Buena Vista International").

### Homage cameos and
parodies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Evil_Queen_\(Disney\)&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Homage cameos and parodies")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Disney_Villainess_Squad_at_WonderCon_2010_Masquerade_5.JPG/220px-
Disney_Villainess_Squad_at_WonderCon_2010_Masquerade_5.JPG)](/wiki/File:Disney_Villainess_Squad_at_WonderCon_2010_Masquerade_5.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Disney_Villainess_Squad_at_WonderCon_2010_Masquerade_5.JPG
"Enlarge")

The "Disney Villainess Squad" cosplayers at [WonderCon](/wiki/WonderCon
"WonderCon") 2010

The character has also made several parodic cameo and homage appearances in
non-Disney media. In the 1945 radio program _[This Is My
Best](/wiki/This_Is_My_Best "This Is My Best")_ , the Queen uttered a curse so
dreadful that the Magic Mirror shattered into a thousand pieces and where the
Queen once stood was nothing but a heap of ashes from which black spiders
crawled and scuffled off into the night. In [Woody Allen](/wiki/Woody_Allen
"Woody Allen")'s live-action film _[Annie Hall](/wiki/Annie_Hall "Annie
Hall")_ (1977), Alvy mentions that when he saw Disney's _Snow White_ , he was
attracted to the Queen while all the other children had a crush on Snow White.
This is followed by an animated sequence of the Wicked Queen, resembling Annie
and voiced by [Diane Keaton](/wiki/Diane_Keaton "Diane Keaton"), talking to
the cartoon version of the daydreaming Alvy, but turns out that even the Queen
scolds him; Alvy attributes it to her having her
[period](/wiki/Menstrual_cycle "Menstrual cycle")
[mood](/wiki/Mood_\(psychology\) "Mood \(psychology\)"), to which the Queen
reminds him she is just a cartoon character.[321]

The Queen was referenced when she appeared as a villain in an issue of Italian
horror comic book series _[Dylan Dog](/wiki/Dylan_Dog "Dylan Dog")_ in
1988.[322] In _[The Simpsons](/wiki/The_Simpsons "The Simpsons")_ episode
"[Four Great Women and a Manicure](/wiki/Four_Great_Women_and_a_Manicure "Four
Great Women and a Manicure")" (2009), the Queen escapes the dwarves after
poisoning Snow White, only to be lynched by a mob of angry woodland
creatures.[323] In the _[U.S. Acres](/wiki/U.S._Acres "U.S. Acres")_ two-part
cartoon "Snow Wade and the 77 Dwarves", Lanolin appears as the Wicked Queen
with a costume is based off the Disney version. In the _[Family
Guy](/wiki/Family_Guy "Family Guy")_ 2009 episode "[Road to the
Multiverse](/wiki/Road_to_the_Multiverse "Road to the Multiverse")",
[Herbert](/wiki/Herbert_\(Family_Guy\) "Herbert \(Family Guy\)") appears as
the disguised Queen. _[The Muppet Show](/wiki/The_Muppet_Show "The Muppet
Show")_ character [Miss Piggy](/wiki/Miss_Piggy "Miss Piggy") is the Queen in
the 2010 parody comic book miniseries _Muppet Snow White_.[324] [Cassie
Scerbo](/wiki/Cassie_Scerbo "Cassie Scerbo") played the Evil Queen in the 2013
[YouTube](/wiki/YouTube "YouTube") parody music video _Cell Block Tango_.[325]
The Queen also appears in _Counting Scars_ , Oh My Disney's Halloween 2014
parody music video of [OneRepublic](/wiki/OneRepublic "OneRepublic")'s
"[Counting Stars](/wiki/Counting_Stars "Counting Stars")".[326][327]
